title: Master Prohibited Words List
description: Master prohibited words list - optimized structure. All content preserved, only format compressed. Version 2.2.1.
usage_instructions: Reference this list in all prompts. Enforce strictly. Prevent reintroduction of terms.
prohibited_phrases: in as much as to say
later that evening as they sat

note_on_weak_language_patterns.description: Weak language patterns (puff words, empty calorie words, inflation words, weasel words, hedge words, filter phrases, cliches, formal hedging, redundant phrases, conversational idioms, overused transitions, and robotic qualifiers) are handled exclusively by Phase 7.
note_on_weak_language_patterns.reference: See 7_weak_language_cleanup.json for complete list of weak language patterns and examples
note_on_weak_language_patterns.reason_for_exclusion: These patterns are only used by Phase 7 and are already embedded in that phase's prompt with full examples and guidance

punctuation_pattern_rules.description: AI tends to overuse em dashes and en dashes for dramatic pauses or appositives. Replace with simpler punctuation.
punctuation_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any use of em dashes (—) or en dashes (–) in the text

replacement_strategy.do: Replace em/en dashes with commas when setting off appositives or parenthetical information
replacement_strategy.avoid: Em dashes (—) or en dashes (–) in any context. These are AI-associated punctuation marks.
alt: Break into two separate sentences using a period
replacement_strategy.note: Em and en dashes are rarely used in natural human writing. When they appear, they're usually a sign of AI-generated text trying to create dramatic pauses or connections.

bad: The proposal—despite its flaws—was accepted.
good: The proposal, despite its flaws, was accepted.

replacements: Use commas for appositives and parenthetical phrases
Use periods to break into separate sentences
Use colons for introducing lists or explanations
punctuation_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ALL em dashes (—) and en dashes (–) in the text. Replace with commas for appositives/parentheticals, periods for sentence breaks, or restructure to eliminate the dash entirely. Never preserve em or en dashes in the output.

dialogue_pause_pattern_rules.description: AI over-describes pauses in dialogue with flowery metaphors. Replace with simple, direct alternatives.
dialogue_pause_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any metaphorical or elaborate description of a pause, silence, or gap in conversation between characters, OR any description that suggests unspoken tension/meaning hanging in the air

replacement_strategy.do: Remove the pause description entirely - let the dialogue speak for itself
replacement_strategy.avoid: Any metaphorical or elaborate descriptions of silence, pauses, or conversational gaps
alt: Use 'Silence.' or 'A pause.' only when the pause is essential to the scene
Use 'Awkward silence.' only when the pause is specifically uncomfortable

bad: The weight of his words hung in the air between them.
good: Silence.

replacements: Silence.
Awkward silence.
A pause.
dialogue_pause_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ANY description of a conversational pause, silence, unspoken tension, or 'things hanging in the air' that uses metaphor, personification, or elaborate language. This includes: pauses described with physical verbs (hung, stretched, settled, filled), silences given qualities (comfortable, loaded, heavy), questions or thoughts described as lingering, and anything suggesting meaning/tension floating between characters. Replace with simple alternatives or remove entirely.

light_description_pattern_rules.description: AI over-describes light with elaborate filtering/casting/reflecting metaphors. Replace with simple, direct alternatives.
light_description_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any description of light that uses verbs like 'filtering', 'casting', 'streaming', 'slanting', or elaborate metaphors for illumination

replacement_strategy.do: Use simple prepositional phrases: 'in the [time] [light source]' (e.g., 'in the afternoon sun', 'in the moonlight')
replacement_strategy.avoid: Verbs like filtering, streaming, slanting, casting, painting with light; elaborate metaphors for illumination
alt: Use direct noun phrases: 'afternoon sun', 'morning light', 'dim room'

bad: Sunlight filtered through the dusty window.
good: In the afternoon sun

replacements: in the moonlight
in the sunlight
afternoon sun
light_description_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ANY description of light/sunlight/moonlight that uses active verbs (filtering, streaming, slanting, casting, painting) or elaborate metaphors. Replace with simple prepositional phrases like 'in the [light source]' or direct nouns like '[time] sun/light'. Prefer removal if the light description doesn't add essential information.

finger_hand_action_pattern_rules.description: AI over-describes finger/hand movements with elaborate verbs instead of simply naming the action. Replace with direct action verbs.
finger_hand_action_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any description of fingers/hands doing an action that focuses on the finger movement rather than the action itself (especially typing, writing, touching)

replacement_strategy.do: Use the direct action verb: 'typing' instead of 'fingers moving across the keyboard'
replacement_strategy.avoid: Elaborate descriptions of finger/hand movements (dancing, hovering, flying, gliding, drumming). Just name the action being performed.
alt: Name the completed action: 'typed', 'wrote', 'touched', 'traced'
replacement_strategy.note: If 'traced' is used for actual tracing (e.g., tracing a scar, tracing a map), keep it. Only replace when it's over-describing a simple action.

bad: My fingers danced across the keyboard.
good: I typed.

replacements: typing
stopped typing
typed
finger_hand_action_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ANY description that focuses on finger/hand movement instead of the actual action being performed. Ask: 'What is the person actually DOING?' Replace with the direct action verb (typing, writing, touching, clicking) without elaborating on finger movements. If the finger/hand description is the only content, replace with the action verb or remove entirely.

meta_analytical_pattern_rules.description: AI generates academic rhetorical analysis language that sounds formulaic and detached. Replace with direct, active descriptions.
meta_analytical_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any meta-analytical description of communication techniques, rhetorical devices, or persuasive strategies using academic terminology

replacement_strategy.do: Remove the meta-analytical framing and use only the direct action verb
replacement_strategy.avoid: Academic rhetorical terminology (ethos, pathos, logos, appeal, builds credibility, establishes authority). Just show the action directly.
alt: Replace 'X by doing Y' with just 'does Y'
replacement_strategy.note: This pattern is extremely common in rhetorical analysis essays and AI-generated content analysis. Always simplify to direct action.

bad: He builds trust by showing confidence in the technology.
good: He shows confidence in the technology.

replacements: Use direct, active verbs showing the action
Replace 'builds trust by showing confidence' with 'shows confidence'
Replace 'uses logic by explaining' with 'explains' or 'breaks down'
meta_analytical_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ANY meta-analytical rhetorical analysis language that describes communication techniques using academic frameworks. Common patterns: 'builds X by Y-ing', 'uses X by Y-ing', 'appeal comes through Y-ing', 'establishes X through Y-ing'. Always replace with the direct action verb only - remove all meta-analytical framing.

false_contrast_rhetorical_pattern_rules.description: AI overuses the 'It's not X, it's Y' rhetorical device to create artificial tension and contrast.
false_contrast_rhetorical_pattern_rules.detection_rule: Any use of the 'It's not [about] X, it's [about] Y' construction or its variants that creates false dichotomies or forced contrasts

why_this_is_problematic.rhetoric_over_reasoning: The construction prioritizes performative contrast over clear explanation of how X and Y actually relate
why_this_is_problematic.forced_tension: Creates artificial tension-release cycles that manipulate rather than inform
why_this_is_problematic.frequency_spam: Appears with such uniformity in AI content that it becomes a detectable signature
why_this_is_problematic.false_dichotomy: Often presents ideas as opposing when they're actually complementary or unrelated
why_this_is_problematic.cadence_signal: The predictable rhythm signals AI-assisted content, especially in video essays and long-form writing

replacement_strategy.do: Remove the false contrast and state the main point (Y) directly
replacement_strategy.avoid: The 'It's not X, it's Y' construction in any of its variants. This is a primary AI signature pattern.
alt: Replace with 'X involves Y' or 'X means Y' to show relationship without opposition
replacement_strategy.note: This pattern is especially prevalent in: marketing copy, video essay scripts, self-help content, business writing, and motivational content. When found, it's a strong AI detection signal.

bad: It's not about managing symptoms. It's about rewriting the narrative of the self.
good: We rewrite the narrative of the self.

patterns: It's not about X. It's about Y.
This isn't just X. It's Y.
This isn't about X. It's about Y.
It's not just about X. It's about Y.
This is not X. This is Y.
The point isn't X. It's Y.
The goal isn't X. It's Y.
replacements: Use direct exposition: State what something IS without contrasting what it ISN'T
Use explicit causality: Explain the relationship between concepts directly
Use assisted inferences: Guide readers to conclusions without false contrast
false_contrast_rhetorical_pattern_rules.detect: Identify ANY construction that follows the 'It's not X, it's Y' pattern or its variants. This includes negating one concept to elevate another in a way that creates false opposition. Common markers: 'It's not [about/just/just about]', 'This isn't [just/about]', 'We're not', followed by contrasting statement with 'It's', 'This is', 'We're'. Replace with direct statements that clarify relationships without performative contrast.

replacement_strategy.primary_approach: Replace with simpler, more natural alternatives
replacement_strategy.secondary_approach: Remove entirely if the word adds no essential meaning
replacement_strategy.consistency_rule: Once a term is replaced, ensure it doesn't reappear in later processing stages

physical_tells_patterns.description: AI identifies emotions through physical reactions, but uses the same limited set of tells repeatedly.
physical_tells_patterns.detection_rule: Any physical reaction described with verbs like tightening, clenching, trembling, catching breath, etc. in emotional context. Look for body parts (hands, breath, jaw, throat, chest, stomach) combined with mechanical emotion-indicators.

replacement_strategy.do: Remove the description entirely and let the character's action speak. If emotion must be shown, use concrete action with consequence, not labeled feeling.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Don't describe the mechanical emotion-tell. These patterns are recognizable as AI defaults.
alt: Describe what the character does because of the emotion: 'She gripped her coffee cup. The liquid sloshed over the rim.' instead of 'Her hands trembled.'
Show the interruption in action/speech: 'He stopped mid-sentence' instead of 'His breath caught.'

bad: Her hands trembled, betraying her anxiety.
good: She gripped her coffee cup. The liquid sloshed over the rim.

replacements: [Delete entirely - let action speak for itself]
She gripped the edge of the table
He held his breath
physical_tells_patterns.detect: Identify ANY physical reaction to emotion that uses mechanical body-part verbs (trembling, clenching, tightening, constricting, catching, etc.). These are AI defaults. Replace by either removing entirely or converting to specific character action with concrete detail.

emotion_intensifier_bans.description: AI uses paper-thin descriptors that 'sound profound but mean nothing.
emotion_intensifier_bans.detection_rule: Texture/fragility language modifying emotion or control-related nouns (patience, control, composure, restraint). Look for: gossamer, threadbare, frayed, worn thin, stretched to breaking, razor-thin, paper-thin.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete the intensifier completely. Often the core noun alone is sufficient.
replacement_strategy.avoid: These texture intensifiers (paper-thin, gossamer, threadbare, etc.) with emotional/control words. They're AI signature patterns.
alt: If intensity must be conveyed, show it through action/consequence, not through fragility language.

bad: His control was paper-thin, stretched to breaking.
good: He hadn't slept. His hands shook slightly.

replacements: [Delete the intensifier entirely]
Show specific evidence: 'He hadn't slept. His hands shook slightly.'
Remove modifier and keep core: 'His control was slipping' instead of 'His control was paper-thin'
emotion_intensifier_bans.detect: Identify intensifiers (paper-thin, threadbare, gossamer, frayed, worn thin, stretched to breaking) paired with emotion/control words. Delete or replace with concrete action showing the emotional state.

transition_beat_placeholders.description: Mechanical delay tactics that interrupt action and momentum. These are pure AI defaults designed to add false suspense without substance.
transition_beat_placeholders.detection_rule: Temporal/pause phrases between action beats, especially those designed to delay revelation: 'for a long moment', 'for a beat', 'for a suspended moment', 'after a moment'. Also patterns like 'when [character] speaks, voice is [adjective]'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Continue directly to the next action or dialogue.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Elaborate descriptions of delays, suspenseful pauses, or emotional beats between actions.
alt: Use one-word beat markers only if essential: 'Silence.' or 'A pause.' - but usually delete even these.

bad: For a long moment, neither of them spoke. The silence that followed was heavy with implication.
good: Silence. She waited for him to continue.

replacements: [Delete entirely and continue to next beat]
Silence.
A pause.
transition_beat_placeholders.detect: Identify temporal delay phrases and suspension beats between actions. Delete them entirely unless there's specific story reason for the delay. Most are mechanical AI padding.

gaze_descriptors.description: These create the appearance of depth and communication without actual substance.
gaze_descriptors.detection_rule: Any adjective describing eyes/gaze that implies knowledge, evaluation, or hidden depths without showing evidence: assessing, appraising, knowing, penetrating, unreadable, inscrutable, cataloguing, measuring, shuttered, guarded, too knowing, seeing too much.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete and show what the look actually communicates through dialogue or action. 'His gaze was unreadable' tells. 'He stared at her without expression' shows. Even better: 'He stared at her. "You're lying."'
replacement_strategy.avoid: Abstract gaze descriptors implying knowledge/evaluation/hidden depths. Let actions and words do the communication.
alt: Use specific action: 'His eyes narrowed' (shows skepticism), 'She looked away' (shows shame or evasion), 'He didn't blink' (shows intensity).

bad: His gaze was too knowing, cataloguing every hesitation.
good: His gaze didn't move from her face. 'You're lying.'

replacements: [Delete the descriptor entirely]
His eyes narrowed
She looked away
gaze_descriptors.detect: Identify abstract gaze descriptors that claim hidden knowledge or depth (assessing, unreadable, inscrutable, etc.) without showing evidence. Delete and replace with specific action or direct communication of what the look means.

temperature_emotion_bans.description: Temperature is 'the most generic descriptor for emotion, narrowing emotional spectrum to two options: hot (angry/passionate) and cold (distant/afraid).
temperature_emotion_bans.detection_rule: Temperature metaphors (hot, cold, warm, ice, fire, frozen, heat, etc.) applied to describe emotional state, fear, passion, or emotional shifts. Look for: 'cold dread', 'heat between them', 'frozen in place', 'fire licked up spine'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Temperature is a lie - emotions don't have temperature.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Temperature metaphors for emotion. Never.
alt: Show specific physical symptom: 'His hands shook' instead of 'Cold fear filled him.'
Show consequence or behavioral change: 'She couldn't focus. Couldn't think.' instead of 'Warmth spread through her.'
replacement_strategy.note: This pattern is especially prevalent in romance and erotica, where it's used to describe physical attraction. Still avoid it.

bad: Cold dread settled in her stomach as she read the letter.
good: She read the letter. Read it again. Her hands wouldn't stop shaking.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
She couldn't focus. Everything else fell away.
His hands shook. He gripped the desk.
temperature_emotion_bans.detect: Identify ANY temperature language (hot, cold, warm, ice, fire, frozen, heat, etc.) used to describe emotion or emotional response. These are universal AI defaults. Delete and replace with specific physical response or behavioral change.

breaking_cracking_metaphors.description: Every emotional shift becomes 'something broke' or 'something cracked.
breaking_cracking_metaphors.detection_rule: Structural failure metaphors (breaking, cracking, shattering, fractured, splintered) applied to emotional/psychological states. Look for: 'something broke', 'something cracked', 'splintered', 'fractured', 'fault lines', 'cracks in foundation'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Replace with specific consequence or behavioral change.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Structural damage metaphors for emotion.
alt: Show what the character does: 'She started crying' instead of 'Something inside her broke.'
Show the specific effect: 'His conviction wavered' instead of 'Cracks appeared in his foundation.'

bad: Something inside him shattered at her words.
good: Her words hit him like a punch. He had to sit down.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
She started crying
His resolve wavered
breaking_cracking_metaphors.detect: Identify structural failure metaphors (breaking, cracking, shattering, fracturing) applied to emotions or psychological states. Delete and replace with specific action showing what changes when the emotional state shifts.

anchor_tether_metaphors.description: Turns connection into passivity—something that happens to the character rather than something chosen.
anchor_tether_metaphors.detection_rule: Anchor/tether metaphors where one person becomes essential to another's stability or sanity: 'the only thing keeping', 'tethered to', 'anchored to', 'held in place', 'moored'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete and reframe as active choice/behavioral change. Show what the character does because of the relationship, not what the other person does for them.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Anchor/tether metaphors for relationships.
alt: Show consequence of separation, not necessity of anchor: 'When she left, he couldn't focus' instead of 'She was his anchor.'

bad: She was the only thing keeping him grounded.
good: When she left, he couldn't focus. Couldn't sleep. Nothing mattered until she came back.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
When she left, he couldn't focus. Nothing mattered until she came back.
He was different when she was there. Better.
anchor_tether_metaphors.detect: Identify anchor/tether language framing one person as essential infrastructure for another's stability. Replace by showing what the character does/feels because of the relationship, not how they're kept in place.

edge_precipice_metaphors.description: Abstract geography substituting for specific psychological state. 'Teetering on the edge' tells when to feel tension; it doesn't create it.
edge_precipice_metaphors.detection_rule: Edge/height/falling language describing emotional or psychological state: 'on the edge', 'precipice', 'barely holding on', 'hanging by a thread', 'teetering', 'one wrong move from'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Let the moment stand on its own.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Metaphorical ledges, edges, or precipices for emotional state.
alt: Show what happens when the character reaches the edge - concrete action/consequence, not abstract position.

bad: He was teetering on the edge of losing control.
good: He opened his mouth. Closed it. Stood up and walked to the window without speaking.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
She opened her mouth. Closed it. Stood up and walked to the window.
He was losing his grip.
edge_precipice_metaphors.detect: Identify edge/precipice language describing emotional state. Delete and replace with specific action showing what happens at the critical moment, not the metaphorical position before it.

time_moment_phrases.description: Evokes camera, not consciousness. 'Time seemed to suspend' tells when to feel tension rather than creating it through character action or thought.
time_moment_phrases.detection_rule: Phrases suggesting time suspension, world-narrowing, or cinematic moments in emotional context: 'time stretched', 'suspended in amber', 'frozen in place', 'the world narrowed to', 'everything else fell away', 'the world held its breath'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete and let the moment stand on its own through character action/dialogue.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Time suspension, world-narrowing, or cinematic narration.
alt: Show through character action/dialogue what makes the moment significant, not through narrative framing.

bad: Time seemed to suspend as their eyes met. The world fell away.
good: She looked up. He was watching her. Neither moved.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
She looked up. He was watching her. Neither moved.
[Let the moment speak through dialogue and action, not narration]
time_moment_phrases.detect: Identify time suspension or world-narrowing phrases. Delete and replace with character action/dialogue showing what makes the moment meaningful.

permission_allowance_patterns.description: Labels release rather than showing what changes when restraint drops. 'She allowed herself to cry' tells; 'She cried, shoulders shaking' shows.
permission_allowance_patterns.detection_rule: Sentences using 'allowed/let/permitted + self + action' structure in emotional context. Look for: 'allowed herself to', 'let himself', 'permitted herself', 'gave herself permission', 'finally let go of'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete the permission framing completely. Show the action directly with sensory detail.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Self-permission constructions.
alt: Drop 'allowed herself to' and 'finally permitted herself to' - just use the action: 'She cried' not 'She allowed herself to cry.'

bad: She allowed herself to cry for the first time.
good: She cried. Actually cried, shoulders shaking, face in her hands.

replacements: [Delete the permission framing entirely]
She cried. Actually cried, shoulders shaking, face in her hands.
He touched her face. Just that. His hand on her cheek.
permission_allowance_patterns.detect: Identify self-permission constructions (allowed/let/permitted + self + verb). Delete the permission framing and show the action directly with concrete detail.

realization_understanding_patterns.description: Tells that realization happened rather than showing thought process or consequence.
realization_understanding_patterns.detection_rule: Phrases suggesting sudden understanding without showing what was understood or its consequence: 'clicked into place', 'pieces slotted together', 'clarity crashed over', 'truth settled', 'landed with the force of', 'crystallized'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete and show what was understood through character dialogue or action in response.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Sudden understanding phrases without showing evidence.
alt: Let character voice the understanding: 'Oh. He's in love with her.' or show action consequence: 'She read the letter twice. She understood.'

bad: Suddenly, clarity crashed over her. She understood everything.
good: She read the letter again. Oh. Oh god. He'd never told her any of it.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
She read the letter again. Oh. Oh god. He'd never told her any of it.
He understood what she meant the moment she said it.
realization_understanding_patterns.detect: Identify sudden-understanding phrases. Delete and replace by showing what the character understands through their dialogue or immediate action/reaction.

danger_threat_descriptors.description: Every dangerous character gets same predator-animal vocabulary.
danger_threat_descriptors.detection_rule: Predator/animal danger vocabulary applied to character descriptions: 'lethal grace', 'predatory', 'coiled to strike', 'dangerous edge', 'barely contained violence', 'quiet menace', 'promise of violence'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Show dangerous behavior through what the character does or the reader's character's response to them, not through animal descriptor.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Predator/animal descriptors for dangerous humans.
alt: Show through action: 'He moved very still, watching her' instead of 'predatory stillness.'
Show through consequence: 'If she ran, he'd catch her' instead of 'lethal grace.'

bad: He moved with lethal grace, predatory stillness in every line.
good: He didn't move. Just watched her. She had the sudden sense that if she ran, he'd catch her.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
He didn't move. Just watched her.
If she ran, he'd catch her. They both knew it.
danger_threat_descriptors.detect: Identify predator/animal danger vocabulary. Delete and show dangerous behavior through action, what the character does, or how others respond to them.

possession_claiming_phrases.description: Same branding metaphor for every intense connection.
possession_claiming_phrases.detection_rule: Ownership/branding metaphors applied to relationships or emotional bonds: 'staked a claim', 'marked', 'claimed', 'branded into', 'written into skin', 'carved into bones', 'imprinted on'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. Show what the character does/thinks/feels because of the connection, not how they're marked by it.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Ownership/branding/marking metaphors for relationships.
alt: Show consequence of connection: 'He thought of her constantly' instead of 'She was branded into his bones.'

bad: He'd branded her into his very bones.
good: Every smell reminded him of her. Every song. He couldn't escape her.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
Every smell reminded him of her. Every song on the radio. He couldn't escape her.
She was part of him now. The thought terrified and exhilarated him.
possession_claiming_phrases.detect: Identify possession/branding/marking language for relationships. Delete and replace by showing what the character does/thinks because of the connection.

religious_exclamations.description: Reflexive intensity markers that tell nothing about character or moment. 'Oh God', 'Jesus', 'Christ' - universal AI default filler.
religious_exclamations.detection_rule: Religious terms used as reflexive exclamations in emotional moments: 'Oh God', 'Oh my God', 'God yes', 'God no', 'Jesus', 'Christ', 'Lord'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. These add nothing.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Generic religious exclamations.
alt: If exclamation is needed, use character-specific ones based on voice/background, not universal defaults.
Replace action trigger: gasped, cursed, stopped mid-breath (showing response) instead of labeling with exclamation.

bad: 'Oh God, I can't—' she gasped.
good: She gasped. 'I can't. Please, I can't.'

replacements: [Delete entirely if possible]
Show what triggers emotional response through action or dialogue
[Use character-specific voice instead of universal default]
religious_exclamations.detect: Identify religious exclamations used as emotional filler. Delete unless deeply character-specific (character who practices religion). Universal defaults are AI signatures.

ending_cliches.detection_rule: Final summary lines that label emotional impact rather than showing it: 'And for now, that was enough', 'It was a start', 'They would figure it out', 'Everything had changed', 'Nothing would ever be the same'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entirely. End with action or dialogue that shows change, not summary that tells it.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Summary closures or 'that was enough' constructions.
alt: Last image/action/dialogue alone is more powerful than summary. Trust it.

bad: They stood together in the dark. And for now, that was enough.
good: They stood together in the dark.

patterns: and for now, that was enough
nothing would ever be the same
replacements: [Delete the summary line entirely]
Let the last action/dialogue stand alone
[Trust the moment to speak for itself]
ending_cliches.detect: Identify summary closures or final lines that label emotional meaning. Delete and let last action/dialogue stand alone.

description_cliches.description: So common they're invisible. Create no specific visual impression. 'Orbs' for eyes, 'mane' for hair, 'sharp planes' - pure template descriptors.
description_cliches.detection_rule: Formulaic descriptor clichés that appear identically in thousands of stories: 'orbs', 'pools', 'mane', 'column of neck', 'delicate wrists', 'line of jaw', 'broad shoulders', 'lean muscle'.

replacement_strategy.do: Delete entire cliché descriptor. Use specific detail unique to character instead.
replacement_strategy.avoid: These cliché descriptors that have appeared in thousands of stories identically.
alt: Use simple, direct description: 'dark eyes' instead of 'pools of darkness.' Or skip entirely.
Describe specific detail showing character: scar, wrinkle, asymmetry, unique feature not the template.

bad: His sharp planes and lean muscle were a study in controlled power.
good: He'd lost weight. The scar on his cheekbone was more visible now.

replacements: [Delete entirely]
Describe something specific/unique to character: his scar, her tattoo, the way his face changed when he smiled
Specific physical detail: 'His hair was too long, falling in his eyes' instead of 'dark mane'
description_cliches.detect: Identify formulaic descriptor clichés that appear identically across thousands of stories. Delete and replace with specific detail unique to your character - scar, tattoo, mannerism, asymmetry. Trust reader's imagination.

dialogue_tag_bans.description: AI over-modifies dialogue tags and voice descriptors with adverbs and flowery language. Humans use simple 'said' or show tone through content.
dialogue_tag_bans.detection_rule: Adverbs modifying 'said' or dialogue: softly, quietly, carefully, flatly, evenly, roughly. Also voice verbs (drops, tightens, breaks, hardens, softens) and qualifiers (deceptively, deliberately, falsely).

replacement_strategy.do: Delete adverb entirely. Use plain 'said' or show tone through dialogue content.
replacement_strategy.avoid: Adverbs modifying 'said'. These are AI defaults. Show don't tell.
alt: Replace adverbial modifiers with action: 'He paused. "I can't do this."' instead of '"I can't do this," he said softly.'

bad: 'I love you,' she whispered softly.
good: 'I love you,' she said.

replacements: [Delete the modifier entirely - use 'said' without adverb]
'I don't know,' she said.
[Show tone through dialogue content, not through modifier]
dialogue_tag_bans.detect: Identify any adverb modifying dialogue or voice verbs describing how something was said. Delete adverbs and show tone through dialogue content or action instead.
